options: Go where email can't reach you
text: Go off-grid with remote escapes, from the San Juan Islands to the Northwest backcountry.
caption: Davis Bay at sunset on Decatur Island. (Megan Burbank / The Seattle Times)

text: Slow down, sit down, binge on Netflix and give yourself permission to do nothing. Or, book a a unique Airbnb close by for a change of scenery with minimal travel.
caption: This treehouse cabin on Lopez Island offers solitude, whimsy and relaxation while close to Seattle. (Sean O'Connell)

text: Sorry, frequent flyer. But if you travel a lot for work, here are some suggestions to make your life easier.
caption: Long lines like those anticipated at airports during summer can be especially frustrating if your job is what takes you out of town, but business travelers can beat the chaos by planning ahead. (Elaine Thompson / The Associated Press)

text: There are the San Juans, and then there's good ol' Bainbridge. Close to Seattle and easily accessible, but far enough that it feels like a getaway.
caption: Isaac Butterfield, 9, and 20-month-old Vesper Angell peer out the window of the ferry as it heads to Bainbridge Island. (Elisa Murray / Special to The Seattle Times)

text: We're not always kind to the planet when we travel. In need of a soothing vacation but want to limit your enviromental impact? Consider these eco-friendly destinations.
caption: Care about the environment? You can take your good intentions with you on vacation. (Jennifer Luxton / The Seattle Times)

text: Pitch a tent, break out the instant cocoa and swap prestige TV for a sky full of stars — for busy professionals and adventurous families, these camping trips are the ultimate escape.
caption: Amanda Gatlin stands on one of the trails in the Lake Wenatchee area. (Jeff Layton / Special to The Seattle Times)

text: Aspiring writer or wannabe chef? A vacation isn't just a way to flee your routine — it can be a chance to devote quality time and energy to something you love and get in touch with your creative side.
caption: A view from the Sou’wester Lodge in Seaview, Pacific County, which offers a creative-residency discount for visitors seeking space to work on music, writer, or visual-art projects. (Ellen M. Banner / The Seattle Times)

text: If you love theater or catching your favorite touring acts at home, you'll love them even more on vacation.
caption: See plays under the sky at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival’s Elizabethan Theatre in Ashland, Oregon. (T. Charles Erickson)

text: David Lynch fan? Extra-interested in extra-terrestrials? There's no need to leave your esoteric interests at home when you travel. Go off the beaten path with a trip tailored to your interests — the weirder the better.
caption: The Great Northern Hotel where FBI agent Dale Cooper stayed on TV's "Twin Peaks" is actually the Salish Lodge & Spa, which overlooks Snoqualmie Falls. (David Israel / Twin Peaks Tour)

text: From birding to Star Wars, a themed journey lets you escape from the ordinary — and makes vacation indecision a thing of the past.
caption: Take a Star Wars-themed road trip to Star Wars: Galaxy’s Edge at Disneyland in Anaheim, California, for all things George Lucas, including this Millennium Falcon simulator. (Disney Parks)

text: Fleeing wildfire smoke and the heat of summer in a city where few residences have AC? Try heading to Alaska.
caption: Alaska cruises frequently take visitors through Glacier Bay. (Reinhard Pantke/ State of Alaska)

text: Not sunny or warm enough for you yet in Seattle? Either stay in Washington and head east, or go south to California.
caption: A view of the Columbia River from the Apple Capital Recreation Loop Trail, a 10-mile paved trail that circles the Columbia River in Wenatchee, passing through waterfront parks and by trailheads. (Crystal Paul / The Seattle Times)

text: Sometimes, all you want is to step outside, flop onto a blanket and stargaze. Can't do that with ambient city lights everywhere. Try this camping trip to La Push.
caption: Rock formations beckon climbers at Second Beach. This is near the northern edge of Quillayute Needles National Wildlife Refuge, named for pointed rocks offshore. (Brian J. Cantwell / The Seattle Times)

text: Stress can literally make you sick. Sometimes a simple getaway isn't enough; you've got to get healthy as well. A wellness retreat might be just the thing to kick the stress and stave off the sniffles at the same time.
caption: Heliconia blooms along the path to a rental cabin at I`olani Farm, carved from an abandoned sugar-cane plantation 45 minutes south of Hilo, Hawaii. (Brian J. Cantwell / The Seattle Times)

text: Sometimes you just need to be around the people who "get it." Affinity group travel is a great way to step away from social circumstances where your experience is uncommon and connect with people who might share common ground.
caption: Volunteers at Earth Gay, an environmental day of service that OUT There Adventures helped facilitate with the Friends of Colman Park, break into small groups to work on different areas of Colman Park. (Crystal Paul / The Seattle Times)

text: Been burning the midnight oil so often lately that your flame's flickering out? Refuel by giving yourself a free pass to pamper yourself and treat yourself to all your favorite indulgences.
caption: Pamper yourself wihtout breaking the bank at one of the best Seattle-area day spas (Gabriel Campanario / The Seattle Times)

text: Tired of traveling for work, but still want to get away from all the chores and responsibilities waiting for you at home? Try a staycation in your hometown for the right dose of away without all the planning and airport security lines.
caption: El Gaucho Seattle has everything you need for a stress-free staycation — a moody bar, live music, fine dining, a movie theater and cozy hotel rooms upstairs. (Crystal Paul / The Seattle Times)

text: If you love to travel but hate to plan it, take the planning out of the equation and sign up for an all-inclusive cruise vacation. Here's a breakdown of the pros and cons to cruises.
caption: Cruising might not be for everyone, but it’s an economic, efficient and popular of mode of travel in Europe and beyond. (Cameron Hewitt / Rick Steves’ Europe)

options: Explore new parts of your city
text: If you don't have time or resources to get out of town, go explore a new neighborhood in Seattle. The city is full of fascinating things to do if you know where to look.
caption: A tour group heads past the Chinese Gate on King Street in Seattle's Chinatown International District. (Alan Berner / The Seattle Times)

text: Whether it's friends, family, or social media, socializing all the time can be stressful. Sometimes you just need to get away from everyone and take some time for yourself.
caption: Pull up a hammock and enjoy the view at Five Mile Drive at Point Defiance Park in Tacoma. (Ken Lambert / The Seattle Times, 2016)

text: Nothing eases the stresses of the family you were born into quite like getting together with the family you chose. A trip with your besties is a great way to detox from family frustrations and strengthen bonds with your ride-or-dies.
caption: Sean Quinton, second from right, and friends hold goats at a farm in the hills above San Simeon, California. (Courtesy of Sean Quinton)

text: Family's great and all, but sometimes you need to inject some new life into your interpersonal relationships. A new activity can help you meet new people from different walks of life and form lasting friendships. One suggestion? Adult summer camp.
caption: A camper leaps during a session at Camp Rahh, a four-night summer camp for adults created by a Seattle man and a group of friends to provide a relaxing, fun, stress-free and unplugged experience. (Brian Oh)

text: Sick of nonstop email notifications and the prevalence of social media? Sign up for a technology retreat or unplug for a weekend.
caption: Sometimes, you just need to get away from the technology all around us. So take a tech retreat and detox.

text: Things moved more slowly back in the day. One way to slow down the pace of life? Take a loooong, scenic train ride.
caption: The Coast Starlight lounge car features floor-to-ceiling windows and lounge chairs where all passengers can enjoy the views. (Crystal Paul / The Seattle Times)

text: Sometimes, texting or calling just isn't the same as a good old-fashioned in-person reunion.
caption: Discovery Park is “kind of the go-to” for hiking within the city, says Craig Romano, author of “Urban Trails: Seattle.” (Erika Schultz / The Seattle Times, 2017)

text: One way to get out of a rut? Learn a new skill. Perhaps you've always wanted to be a rock star? You can do that here.
caption: Guitarists Emily Spahn, left, and Kelly MacDicken and bassist Elizabeth Baker huddle at their band’s first practice session at Ladies Rock Camp. (Alan Berner / The Seattle Times)

text: An adventure can mean an ambitious solo hike, or it can simply mean a weekend getaway to pick up a new winter sport.
caption: For anyone who grew up around snow, sledding is a cherished winter tradition. And if you’re the kind of person who only stubbornly gave up your childhood pursuit, riding a luge is a next-level adult thrill ride. (Jeff Layton / Special to The Seattle Times)

text: If you're the sort who typically over-plans travel, switch it up and allow yourself room to just be spontaneous.
caption: The Cascade Loop showcases the geographic diversity of Washington in all its beauty and takes you to places you might never have visited (Stefanie Loh / The Seattle Times)
